comments.commentBody: There are a lot of excellent suggestions here.  I would add or reiterate a couple of them.  We took our kids last year when they were 11 and 14.  First, rent an apartment.  The rates are better than hotels and the ability to spread out is very important.  Second, we took a bike tour of the city and really enjoyed that.  The street level view and the ability to go through neighborhoods (not just tourist areas) was terrific.  Third, my kids loved Luxembourg Gardens.  Sailing the boats is fun and I am surprised that no one has mentioned the playground.  An amazing place, even for the 14 year old.  And it is near the carousel.  We also visited Notre Dame, Louvre, D'Orsay, Tuileries, Eiffel Tower, all with great success.  Don't miss the Eiffel Tower light show at night.

Couldn't agree more on the Emissions and Power !!

We had to replace a small old HP laser. Because of the Web articles on the toxicity of laser emissions, I recently bought a brand-name inkjet.

It is a heavy monstrosity of a thing which creates so much vibration on the desk, I will have to buy a special stand and move it far from the computer, monitor, etc before it destroys the sensitive electronics in everything else we own.

Built-in networking has been around for a while. Any HP laser printer with an "n" in the model name had it. Same with duplex printing (those models have a "d".) Same with automatic driver installation. AirPrint might be new, though.

I wish printer reviews covered two more things than they usually do: power consumption, and particulate emissions. I found a report saying my particular printer, an HP 2520d, was particularly bad for spewing toner into the air. Not good for your lungs, and probably totally unregulated.

I agree here. Yes, we have cool electronic gadgets (but still no laser guns!) which I never would have dreamed of 40 years ago, but the infrastructure, and how we get around, has been a HUGE disappointment. Even the cars are ugly, boxy things, not the cool, futuristic, streamlined vehicles with airy glass domes I thought would be plying the roads, powered by electricity, not noisy, smelly gasoline engines. And the US has failed miserably to keep up with other countries building high-speed rail. We even killed the space program. We were on pace to have a lunar base by the 1980s, visit Mars in the 1990s, and have a Mars base by now, with exploration to the outer planets. Instead, we haven't gone past low-Earth orbit since Apollo 17.

And the places people live have been equally disappointing. "New" homes that are faux versions of old styles, complete with "fake" window panes. None of the nice, futuristic stuff I thought we would have. It's as if people have no vision, and want to live in the 1950s forever, except it's a 1950s with far more gadgets. Heck, we don't even use these gadgets to their full potential. Since this article is about how we get around, we could largely solve many of our transportation woes if all jobs which could be done at home (easily 50%) were done at home. But of course, management is rooted in the 1950s also, so you have to drive 30 miles to sit at a computer. Really, other than a few high notes, like LED lighting, the future has been a big letdown.

Dr. L. Harrison, PhD --- Since Fukushima Dai-ichi incident the UAE started the construction of 4 nuclear power plants, the Vietnamese started on their second, the  Bangladeshis started on their first as did the Turks.  In fact, I know of no canceled orders at all.  The Chinese did revise their long term plan to a lower build rate.  At the same time, Jordan is pushing towards the choice of their first and the Finns have chosen their second.  The Czechs are still choosing as are the Hungarians and the Bulgarians.

I agree with both Stiglitz and Minsky. Financial frictions and harmful deregulation are a problem, but at the same time it is hard to separate society's fundamental problems from inequality and seems illogical to separate inequality from indebtedness when the poor and middle class have a larger marginal propensity to consume. Indebtedness seems to have also come from living in the wealthiest country in the world. In order to function in such a society one must be able to afford certain goods and services. For example in many parts of the country, it is hard to function without a car which comes with insurance, registration and maintenance. If society were more equal certain necessities would be more affordable and indebtedness would be less. But instead stagnant real wages and large increases in the cost of living, because the poor live in the wealthiest country in the world, have driven up consumer debt.

I had several when I closed my office in 2009.  At that point there was a glut of used office equipment on the market, so I just gave them away.  I kept a HP 4000T that I must have bought in mid-1990s and a 6P.  Both still working at home.  Slow yes, but rock steady machines.  Gotta say tho that the 3 were really well built.

Another great column from Mr. Egan. I'm an early-years boomer - '49 - and just beginning to figure out how to live on terms that don't revolve entirely around service - to my family, my employers(s), my colleagues, and my intermittently dominant ideals about human relations and purposes.

I always preferred John to Paul - the edgier Beatle, y'know? - but I completely credit Mr. Egan for pointing out how important it is to rock out, always.

Realistically, it's not surprising today's youth think cars are uncool. For one thing, the vast majority of cars on the road are ugly as sin, especially SUVs. There's none of the cool, ultrastreamlined stuff with glass domes on top depicted in futurist's dreams. And most of these cars are powered by an equally unappealing, antiquated, noisy, smelly internal combustion engine. Today's youth are quite familiar with the concept of plugging things in to recharge them. It's not a stretch to imagine a car with which they can do the same might have some appeal, provided it looked cool as well. While we're at it, why not reduce the size to something more in keeping with the fact that most cars rarely carry more than the driver? Make something with three wheels instead of four which tilts in turns. Make it ultra streamlined so you can get 200 miles or more range from a small battery. Keep the weight under 500 pounds, the length under 10 feet. Sell it for under $10,000. There's a car which might appeal to some of today's youth who might otherwise have zero desire to own any car. And such a vehicle would be eminently more sensible for the vast majority of drivers than a 3 ton SUV with a 300 HP gasoline engine. The car really needs to evolve into something other than the overpowered, huge, ugly behemoth it has become if it is to appeal to more than just the mainly over 50 demographic.

Laszlo,

Excellent addition to the blog as always.

I love the fact that you did the math on the Quincy recos!!

It's hilarious on its own, but what makes it even funnier is that Husband used one of those 19 comments to specifically say he was going to Wife's computer to give recos to some of his own comments!

That fact makes the math mind-boggling.

Mr. Hughes, I guess that on that day, you were Wordplay's MVP: Most VERBOSE Player!

-- Most Tickled Fanofblindauer

MTF, It's screamingly obviously you've been dying to get back at me for that MVP crack I made at your expense, about two weeks ago.
"Revenge is a dish best served cold", is it not? LOL

Have a good Friday, my friend, as well as your weekend

Howie TBOQ

All in fun, sir.

And in this weather, EVERYTHING is best served cold.

-- Most Terse Funster

Two superb late-week showings in a row: an excellent BEQ after a magnificent Blindauer. It is the greatest one-two punch in recent memory. Maybe last Fri-Sat's P.Berry-Tim Croce duo came close.

Any puzzle with SEA OTTER in it cannot be bad, but what does ABBA EBAN have to do with EUROPOP?

NORSEMAN: Portmanteau of horseman and North.
HIED: How Johnny Carson greeted his co-host.
OSH: Northern half of Wisconsin city, b'gosh.
RENAIL: Kidney with a nail in it = failure.
INFER: First question to a new inmate, after "whatcha."
ERODENT: Computer mouse.

A thoroughly enjoyable puzzle by BEQ, challenging but utterly doable and quite satisfying.

My favorite part of yesterday's blog was Librarose's 10 recos for her single comment vs. Howie's 14 total for his 19 comments. That alone was worth the trouble of wading through all that gushing.

Canadian wages are a Provincial jurisdiction.
In Quebec, the minimum wage is 10.50. It's considered a living wage as rents, say in Montreal vary from $400 - $600 a month
for a 1 bedroom apt..
As in Australia, healthcare is universal and free !
Employees are entitled to 20 working days holidays or 4%. there are 11 paid holidays in Quebec Province. All workers are entitled to parental leave and caregiver's leave. (Our parental leave is one of the most generous)
Still our corporations make supersized profits ! Our 5 major banks made over $40B last year, and paid their CEO's 8 figure salaries !!

You're economic ignorance is beyond the pale. Like, most Marxists your delusions sounds wonderful to the blissfully ignorant. Minimum wage increase mandates destroy jobs, and destroy starter Job opportunities for millions of America's youth. I cite sources and direct you to data which unequivocally refutes all of your noxious drivel; but since you're obviously educated, it's clear you aren't concerned with the facts.
Unfortunately for you; the delusional nonsense you blather only works in fantasy utopia land. Fast Food Jobs are Starter jobs, which serve to acclimate people with the workforce. Minimum Wage Jobs aren't career jobs, nor are they intended to serve as career positions for people raising families.

R, if you, Obama, Pelosi, and Elizabeth Warren think it is so easy to do this -- why haven't y'all done it yet?

Why?

We’re the richest country on earth. If Australia can afford to pay their workers a living wage and provide universal health care (which would get health care off the backs of businesses), why can’t the US do the same?

The minimum wage in Australia is $16.37; their unemployment rate is 5.7 percent. The argument that raising the rate would lead to job losses is not supported by the facts.

Minimum wage rates for Australian workers:
$16.37 – adults
$16.00 – 20 years of age
$13.51 – 19 years of age
$11.18 – 18 years of age
$9.46 – 17 years of age
$7.74 – 16 years of age
$6.03 – under 16 years of age

http://www.fairwork.gov.au/pay/national-minimum-wage/Pages/default.aspx

Part-time workers and temp workers receive 24 percent in cash compensation in lieu of benefits. Full-time workers receive 10 sick days, 20 vacation days, and 10 or more paid holidays. All workers are entitled to parental leave and caregiver’s leave, and extra vacation is provided to shift workers.

Fair Work, Fair Pay: Lessons From Australia
http://truth-out.org/opinion/item/5601

“The real difference between the two countries, though, appears in company profits. American companies make far more in profits than Australian companies. Over the past ten years, the profits of corporations and proprietors have amounted to an average of ‘20.4 percent’ of America’s national income. The equivalent figure in Australia is ‘12.7 percent.’

“It’s hard to make super-sized profits when you have to pay a living wage.”

Thanks Mark Bittman. Until all of our jobs offer a decent living wage, we cannot have gender or racial or ethnic equality. We cannot really have democracy if people must work without getting paid a living wage.

Such low wages are in fact not part of a free market system - they are set by cartels of super rich people with super communications among them, controlling prices and costs to deliberately pay people less than they need to live on.

This is what America has come to - a giant Ponzi scheme to enrich the super rich and impoverish and sicken our environment and 90% of all workers.

If we want to protect our environment for everyone, we cannot treat animals or people as badly as the "food" industry. It is killing us and killing our democracy.

We traveled with our 4 year old to Paris a few years ago. A highlight was the Promenade Plantee, the elevated tree-lined walkway. It was an excellent, interesting walk, and even goes through a park with a play-structure at one point. Walking up to the 2nd level of the Eiffel tower was great too.
As others have mentioned renting an apartment was helpful, as was using the Metro to get around. Our son enjoyed mapping out where to go, on which line etc. We also paced ourselves with just one 'big' thing and some park/play-structure time daily.
We had excellent meals, often lunches, as well as fun expeditions to the boulangerie and MonoPrix for in-apartment dinners or picnics.
Two museums we liked were Musee des Arts et Metiers De Paris and Musee de L'Orangerie. Both had cool things to enjoy/interact with, but were small enough to not give us museum fatigue.
Go, relax, have fun!
You're talking about free wi-max coverage...which would inevitably be paid for by taxpayers.

An iPad device that could work without the need for expensive cellular service like the GPS app which is built into the cellular iPad even when there isn't any cellular service. Just like the Navigational system works on my Honda or Garmin without additional contracts (Monthly or otherwise).  In other words cutting the umbilical cord from the telephone companies. Just imagine all of your apps working on your iPad or mobile computing device without the telephone carriers!!

This is a Greek Tragedy, played out as farce. It's really, really sad. Weiner was such a wonderful spokesperson for the left of center, progressive wing of the Democratic Party. Now he's a punch line. I see no future for him. Bottom line, though, the best thing for him would be to get out of the race, next week. In fact, I predict he will.
It's tragic. Both for the progressives and liberals in this country, already under siege from a relentless, ruthless right-wing assault; but more poignantly, for a once-promising man, and his put-upon wife.
There are serious issues and a whole city to run. If he has any respect he should take his wiener to a psychiatrist.

Nonsense! I am a former New Yorker, and well understand the issues facing the City even though I no longer live there. The issues are similar in every large city: the gap between the wealthy and the poor, lack of affordable housing, the need for better transportation, and the delivery of basic services, among others. Weiner should not be the next mayor because he has shown himself to be, at the very least, a man of extraordinarily poor judgment and weak character. I firmly believe that what you say and do in private bleeds over into your public persona. My hometown can do better!

Why on Gods green earth would anyone vote for a compulsive lair with obvious addiction issues which is already an embarrassment *at the least * and blackmail *just the er, tip of the iceberg?

Seriously people, his penis was published on thedirty for the World To See. Who but family or political friends expecting favors, would back this guy?

Sorry. He habitually texts shots of his erect penis to college girls. Unfortunately, that inconvenient fact has to be considered part of (a) his experience, and (b) his ideas. It's an addiction. They're inseparable, until he gets a lot of help over a long period of time. He's not well. And by supporting his candidacy, his wife is enabling him. It's tragic.

In the recesses of his mind, this all may have been part of the plan.  He was unable to stop his self-destructive behavior, and unable to truly come clean to his wife.  The only way to force himself to face the issue was to let the public suss it out again.  Sad.

A 23-year old political science major willingly and knowingly had phone sex and sexting with a widely recognized and troubled male public servant she knew was married.  Why?  I realize age 23 is young, but its not that young.  I wish I could be certain her motivations are well-intended and that Anthony Weiner doesn't have an addiction, but its hard to believe that given their mutual tango of deceit and deception.  There are no victims here, only participants.

Consider this born New Yorker as totally in agreement with the "censorial missives."

If he had a blameless personal sexual life, his tenure would merely be a terrible letdown, considering his total lack of executive know-how; his non-existent experience in city and State politics; and his record of not getting along with any of his colleagues; but while NYC would be damaged, one good mayor after him could probably fix the hash he would obviously make of things.

But when you throw in his sexual proclivities, his narcissism, his total lack of candor, he would be perhaps the biggest disaster as mayor since Boss Tweed.

The international snicker factor alone would tear at the sinews of this great city.

I enjoy reading these comments very much. People feel strongly about this 'issue.' In San Diego, our current mayor is in the hot seat for sex related allegations. It seems that the whole city is talking (and laughing) about this one thing. Are these men really the monsters they are being portrayed as? Of course not. However, now that this media spectacle has taken hold, it's like sharks at the carcass...a frenzy of wild, a

Has anyone checked to see if he ever used a phone given to him by his employers (the gov't) to do this sexting? Every workplace in America has strict rules about proper use of work phones and the internet. He violated that if he used a work phone.

From what we know so far, Weiner did not break any law. What he does in his free time is really nobody's business. Besides, has anybody checked Facebook, craigslist and all those other sites where people post everything and more about themselves. Or all the reality TV programs where people expose more than their private parts. I could not care less about this story. Private lives are private. All those outraged people should really check their own closet so to say before getting all moral. I find so much more "pornographic" the fact that we live in a city where there's outrageous wealth next to extreme appealing poverty. That New Yorkers have to wait for years to get access to public housing. Or the state of public schools and our criminal (in)justice system. Who cares about private sex pictures, when you have no job, bad schools, terrible housing and you are locked up for looking suspicious?

How is it "personal" when he sends out photos of his penis over phones and therefore over the internet?  This is vastly different from what Clinton did.  I also remember that some of these women didn't expect and may not have wanted these photos.  That would constitute harassment (exhibitionism) in my book.  I certainly don't want to pick up my phone and have to see some guy's penis when I'm trying to get through the day.

I am glad I am not a citizen of NYC right now...I would be embarrassed to admit being a citizen of NYC mainly because the city is even entertaining the idea of letting this weiner run for mayor, and along with his overly ambitious, calculating wife, really woman?
